title: RS20702
content: The Water Resources Development Act of 2000 authorized federal agencies to participate in Everglades restoration projects under the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan. The Everglades is crucial to the South Florida ecosystem, which includes national wildlife refuges and national park units. Changes in water quantity, quality, and distribution since the 1950s have significantly impacted the region's ecology. Florida is home to over six million people and a large agricultural economy. Changes in water quantity and quality since the 1950s have significantly impacted the region's ecology, leading to water shortages during the dry season. The Everglades in Florida, affected by lower rainfall in 2007, are expected to face more frequent water shortages as urban and agricultural demand increases. The Everglades in South Florida were once rich in species diversity, but by the mid-1800s, they were viewed as unproductive swamps. Human interventions like the C&SF project altered the hydrology with canals and levees for flood control and development. The C&SF project by the Army Corps of Engineers in South Florida, authorized in 1948, altered the Everglades' water regime with canals and levees. This changed water flow from Lake Okeechobee, leading to less water during the dry season and more during the rainy season. The Everglades ecosystem has changed due to altered water flow from Lake Okeechobee, leading to habitat loss and reduced size. Urban and agricultural development have further impacted the ecosystem with degraded water quality from pollutants like excess nutrients and pesticides. The plan focuses on capturing and storing freshwater for use during the dry season, with an estimated cost of nearly $20 billion, $10.9 billion of which would be spent under CERP. CERP aims to restore natural hydrologic functions, improve water quality, and provide water supplies by capturing and storing freshwater for use during the dry season. Approximately 80% of the captured water would be directed to the natural system, with the remaining 20% for agricultural and urban consumption. The plan involves removing 240 miles of levees and canals, building reservoirs, underground storage wells, and pumping stations to replicate natural flow. Title VI of WRDA 2000 approved CERP as part of the Final Integrated Feasibility.
